HIGH-DIMENSIONAL STATISTICAL INFERENCE

The use of the Central Limit Theorem (CLT) and Bootstrap techniques has become increasingly essential in high-dimensional statistical inference. These methods enable us to approximate the distributions of key statistics that arise during the inferential process for complex models.

For instance, consider the probability that a set of Kolmogorov-Smirnov type statistics falls below specific thresholds
P(
max
j∈Jk
SXnj ≤ tk for all k= 1,...,κ
) = P(
SXn ∈ A
)
can be approximated by P( SYn ∈ A), with a corresponding error margin of ρn(Are). Here, {Jk} represents non-overlapping subsets of {1,...,p }, {tk} are thresholds within the interval (-∞, ∞), κ ≥ 1 is an integer, and A ∈ Are is a hyperrectangle defined as
{w∈ Rp : max j∈Jk wj ≤ tk for all k= 1,...,κ }.

Similarly, we can approximate the probability that a set of Pearson type statistics falls below specific thresholds:
P(
∥(SXnj)j∈Jk ∥2 ≤ tk for all k= 1,...,κ
) = P(
SXn ∈ A
)
can be approximated by P( SYn ∈ A), with an associated error margin ρn(Are).
